title: Wimdu guide to table manners around the world

Unrefined table manners can be one of the biggest slip-ups for holidaymakers when they head abroad, especially when they fail to research the local customs before leaving home.
Not knowing how to toast fellow punters at a pub in Budapest or which utensil to eat with at a restaurant in Bangkok can cause embarrassment or even offend locals.
But this etiquette guide offers a number of tips to help tourists avoid a faux pas when they sit down for dinner at restaurants in places such as Paris, Tokyo and Mexico City.
Holidaymakers who are eating at a restaurant in Japan should be careful where they put their chopsticks
The infographic, created by travel website Wimdu, takes a look at table manners around the world, including France, where tourists should be mindful about where they place their hands when they are seated.
When they’re not using their utensils they should rest their wrists or forearms on the table (never their elbows).
They should never keep their hands on their lap, where they would be out of sight from other diners.

In Germany, holidaymakers who are stuffing their faces between gulps of beer at Oktoberfest or any restaurant need to be careful when they are eating potatoes.
The infographic suggests they mash the potatoes with a fork and never use a knife to cut them. Doing so means you don’t think the potatoes have been cooked properly.
Spain is one of British tourists’ favourite destinations, but they shouldn’t get up and leave once the meal is finished.
According to local customs, they should enjoy sobremesa, the period after eating in which diners relax and chat while allowing their food to digest.
For those who are visiting Britain, etiquette rules apply when they are eating asparagus as a starter with a dip or dressing.
Never use utensils to cut it up into pieces. Instead, diners should use their fingers and pick up an individual piece from the end of the stem.
Visitors to Japan need to be mindful when they’re eating rice with chopsticks, as they may bring about bad luck.
When they’re not being used for eating, chopsticks should be left horizontal on the table – never upright in the bowl, as that is how food is offered to the dead at Japanese Buddhist funeral ceremonies.
In Hungary, locals do not toast with beer, while in Thailand it is rude to use a fork to transfer food to your mouth.
Instead, use a fork to push food onto a spoon, which is used for eating.
